title: How to calm your anxiety, from a neuroscientist - Wendy Suzuki

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main argument about anxiety?

options.label: A
options.text: Anxiety is a completely negative emotion that should be avoided at all costs.

options.label: B
options.text: Anxiety is a helpful tool that can be used to avoid danger and protect us.

options.label: C
options.text: Anxiety is a neutral emotion that has no impact on our lives.

options.label: D
options.text: Anxiety is a completely positive emotion that brings us joy and happiness.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main reason why we don't feel protected by anxiety?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our individual and collective anxiety levels are too high.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we are not using anxiety correctly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because anxiety is not a natural part of human evolution.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are not aware of the signs of anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first tool the author recommends for turning down the volume on anxiety?
What is the "boxed breathing" approach the author recommends?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhale for 2 counts, hold for 2 counts, exhale for 2 counts, hold for 2 counts.

options.label: B
options.text: Inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4 counts, exhale for 4 counts, hold for 4 counts.

options.label: C
options.text: Inhale for 6 counts, hold for 6 counts, exhale for 6 counts, hold for 6 counts.

options.label: D
options.text: Inhale for 8 counts, hold for 8 counts, exhale for 8 counts, hold for 8 counts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second tool the author recommends for turning down the volume on anxiety?
According to the author, what are some examples of beneficial neurochemicals released when we move our body?

options.label: C
options.text: Oxytocin, vasopressin, and atrial natriuretic peptide.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's recommendation for incorporating movement into our daily lives?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to move for at least 30 minutes a day.

options.label: B
options.text: Take a short walk around the block or do a few jumping jacks.

options.label: C
options.text: Engage in high-intensity exercise for at least an hour a day.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid movement altogether and focus on relaxation techniques.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what happened to the anxiety scores of the NYU students after they participated in a movement session?

options.label: B
options.text: Their anxiety scores remained the same.

options.label: C
options.text: Their anxiety scores decreased to normal levels.

options.label: D
options.text: Their anxiety scores became more severe.

multiple-choice.question: What are two important things that will happen once we connect with our body and turn the volume down on our anxiety?

options.label: A
options.text: We will be able to communicate more effectively with others and use our anxiety for its intended purpose.

options.label: B
options.text: We will be able to avoid danger and protect ourselves from harm.

options.label: C
options.text: We will be able to reduce our stress levels and feel more fulfilled.

options.label: D
options.text: We will be able to increase our anxiety levels and feel more anxious.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's wish for every one of us?

options.label: A
options.text: To be completely free from anxiety and stress.

options.label: B
options.text: To be able to communicate more effectively with others and use our anxiety for its intended purpose.

options.label: C
options.text: To be able to reduce our stress levels and feel more fulfilled.

options.label: D
options.text: To be able to increase our anxiety levels and feel more anxious.

title: Ugly History: The U.S. Syphilis Experiment - Susan M. Reverby

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary cause of syphilis in the United States during the 1930s?
What were some of the existing treatments for syphilis at the time?
What was the main goal of the Tuskegee study in Alabama?

options.label: A
options.text: To investigate the effects of syphilis on the cardiovascular system

options.label: B
options.text: To observe how syphilis would progress with minimal treatment

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new treatment for syphilis

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of penicillin on syphilis

options.label: A
options.text: To provide free medical care to the participants

options.label: B
options.text: To recruit participants and conduct the study

options.label: C
options.text: To investigate the effects of syphilis on the population

options.label: D
options.text: To provide penicillin to the participants

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the study's leadership to withhold knowledge of new treatments from the participants?

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the participants from accessing penicillin

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the participants from the risks of treatment

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the study in terms of the racial differences in the progression of syphilis?

options.label: A
options.text: The study confirmed that syphilis affected the cardiovascular system of white patients and the neurological system of Black patients

options.label: B
options.text: No evidence of any racial difference was discovered

options.label: C
options.text: The study found that syphilis affected both white and Black patients equally

options.label: D
options.text: The study was inconclusive in its findings

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the study on the participants and their families?

options.label: A
options.text: Only 74 of the original 600 men were alive when the study ended

options.label: B
options.text: 40 of the participants' wives and 19 of their children contracted syphilis

options.label: C
options.text: The study led to the development of a new treatment for syphilis

options.label: D
options.text: The study had no impact on the participants or their families

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the federal investigation and lawsuit following the exposé of the study?

options.label: A
options.text: The study was shut down in 1972 and the participants were provided with treatment

options.label: B
options.text: The study was continued and the participants were provided with penicillin

options.label: C
options.text: The study was shut down in 1972, but the participants were not provided with treatment

options.label: D
options.text: The study was deemed unethical, but the participants were not affected

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Tuskegee study on medical research and ethics?

options.label: A
options.text: The study led to the development of new regulations for informed consent

options.label: B
options.text: The study led to the development of new treatments for syphilis

options.label: C
options.text: The study highlighted the need for transparency in research and the importance of informed consent

options.label: D
options.text: The study had no impact on medical research and ethics

multiple-choice.question: What is the ongoing issue in medical care and research in the US?

options.label: C
options.text: Systemic racism in medical care and research
